questions.text: A 55-year-old female fell on her left shoulder while walking and now presents with severe pain, swelling, and bruising. Based on the X-ray shown below, what is the most common mechanism of injury and the likely affected structure?

options.label: B
options.text: Fall on an outstretched hand, Radial nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Fall on an outstretched hand, Axillary nerve

questions.correct_answer: D. Fall on an outstretched hand, Axillary nerve
questions.explanation:
Proximal Humerus Fracture

Shaft of Humerus Fracture

Mechanism of injury

Fall on an outstretched hand (Option D)

Direct trauma (Option C)

Structures affected
  • Axillary artery
  • Axillary nerve (Option D)
  • Brachial artery
  • Radial nerve (Option C)

Complications

  • Joint stiffness (most common)
  • Avascular necrosis (AVN)
  • Nerve injury:
    • Axillary nerve (most common)
    • Suprascapular nerve injury
  • Non-union
  • Shoulder dislocation
  • Myositis
  • Malunion

Early:

  • Nerve injury: Radial nerve (wrist drop)
 

Late:

  • Delayed and non-union
  • Joint stiffness

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling in her right forearm after a biking accident. She has difficulty flexing her ring and pinky fingers. Examination reveals swelling, limited flexion of the fourth and fifth fingers, pallor, diminished pulse, and paresthesia in the affected fingers. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Type

Management

Mild

(Tsuge's Type-I)
  • Turn Buckle's splint (Volkmann's splinting) (Option A)

 
  • Physiotherapy
  • Total excision (single muscle involved)

Moderate

(Tsuge's Type-II)
  • Max page's operation (Soft tissue sliding operation) (Option B)

 

  • Excision of cicatrix
  • Neurolysis (freeing the peripheral nerves from the surrounding fibrous tissue)

Severe

(Tsuge's Type-III)
  • Seddon's carpectomy: (Option C)

 

  • Excision of the scar
  • Arthrodesis of the wrist
  • Amputation (cases with gangrene) (Option D)

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with a history of a left lateral condylar fracture presents with left elbow pain, especially during lifting or reaching overhead. She notices her left arm appears straighter than her right. Examination shows lateral deviation of the forearm when her arms are extended. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description

An acquired deformity due to reduced growth on the lateral side of the distal humeral epiphysis.

Cause

Non-union of lateral condylar fracture

Clinical feature
  • A carrying angle of the elbow greater than 15 degrees
  • Asymmetry between the two side
  • Lateral deviation of the forearm during arm extension

 

Management

  • Usually, no treatment is required
  • Supracondylar osteotomy (in severe cases)

Complication

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy: Managed by anterior transposition of the ulnar nerve.

Description

A lateral closed wedge osteotomy.

Approach

Posterior triceps split

Procedure

X-ray

Indication

Cubitus varus correction

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling from a tree. X-rays reveal a displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus. The child is experiencing severe pain, and upon examination, the forearm appears swollen and tense. Which of the following is the first sign of impending compartment syndrome??

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of the radial pulse on examination

options.label: B
options.text: Pain that intensifies with passive finger extension

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate improvement in pain with elevation of the arm

questions.correct_answer: B. Pain that intensifies with passive finger extension

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a fall while playing rugby. He has severe pain and swelling in his elbow, and the physician suspects injury to the terrible triad. Which of the following is NOT a component of the terrible triad of the elbow?
questions.correct_answer: D. Fracture of the medial epicondyle

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the emergency department after falling on an outstretched hand. The examination reveals swelling and tenderness over the lateral aspect of the elbow. X-rays show the findings as shown in the image. What classification system is used to categorize this condition?

A 10-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after falling onto an outstretched hand. X-rays reveal a finding, as shown in the image. Traction is applied as part of the management, as depicted in the accompanying image. What is the name of the traction being used?
A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department after falling onto an outstretched hand. X-ray shows the following findings. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Long arm cast immobilization for 3 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Closed reduction and percutaneous pinning
questions.explanation:
Gartland Classification of Supracondylar Fractures

Type I

Nondisplaced fractures.

Long arm cast immobilisation

(Option A) for 3 weeks, followed by a period of protected activity

Type II

Fracture with an intact posterior hinge.

 

Type IIA

Stable fractures with no significant

translation or rotation

Closed reduction & casting (Option B)

Type IIB

Unstable fractures with some degree of translation or rotation

Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation

Type III

Completely displaced fractures.

Closed reduction and pinning

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy fell on his outstretched hand and was presented with pain, swelling and restricted movement of the elbow, along with an S-shaped deformity. An X-ray was performed; What is the most common type of below fracture diagnosed?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Extension type

Flexion Type

Frequency

More common

Rare (Option A and C)

Location

The distal part of the humerus is extended.

The distal part of the humerus is flexed

Subtypes
  • Posteromedial (more common)
  • Posterolateral (Option B)
  • Anteromedial
  • Anterolateral

Complications
  • Radial nerve injury (Posteromedial)
  • Median nerve injury (Posterolateral)
  • Vascular injury: Brachial artery damage is most common, leading to peripheral ischemia
  • Ulnar nerve injury

X-ray

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with difficulty flexing the distal phalanx of her index and middle fingers, along with weakness in thumb opposition and forearm pronation. He also reports pain, swelling, and limited movement in his elbow following a fall on his left hand. An X-ray was taken. Which of the following nerves is commonly affected in this condition?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

Types
  • Type 1: Undisplaced fracture
  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation
  • Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the "hand of benediction" sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected.
  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

X-ray Findings
  • Three bony parts relationship is maintained.
  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.

 
  • Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 
  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.

 
  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

 

Management

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)
  • In Late presentation with swelling
    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications
  • Early complications
    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the clinic after falling on her outstretched hand, resulting in severe pain in her left elbow. The examination shows swelling and tenderness in the elbow, and she is reluctant to move her arm. An x-ray has been taken. Which of the following is false regarding the 3 bony point relationship in this fracture?

options.label: A
options.text: Three points form a nearly isosceles triangle when the elbow is flexed at 90°.

options.label: B
options.text: Medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, and tip of the olecranon are the three bony points.

options.label: C
options.text: Bony relationship is unaffected by elbow fractures.

options.label: D
options.text: Bony point relationship are unaffected in Supracondylar fractures

questions.correct_answer: C. Bony relationship is unaffected by elbow fractures.
questions.explanation:
Type of Injury

Supracondylar Fracture

Elbow Dislocation

Frequency

Common fracture in children

Common dislocation in children

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand, hyperextension

Fall on outstretched hand, posterior force on flexed elbow

Three bony points relationship

Maintained

Reversed (Option B)
(Bowstringing of Triceps tendon)

Length of forearm

Normal

Shorter

Types

Gartland classification (3 types: I, II, III)

No specific classification

Nerve damage

Anterior interosseous nerve

Median nerve

X-ray

Anterior humeral line displaced, visible fracture.

Dislocation of radius and ulna with displaced humeral condyle.


 

Complications and Deformities
  • Compartment syndrome (Volkmann's ischemic contracture)
  • Brachial artery injury
  • Gunstock deformity (cubitus varus) in untreated cases.

 
  • Medial collateral ligament (MCL) or lateral collateral ligament (LCL) damage resulting in recurrent dislocations or subluxations.
  • Posterior olecranon deformity (abnormal prominence of the olecranon process)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left upper arm and wrist drop after a fall while playing football. Examination reveals weakness in wrist extension and numbness over the dorsum of his hand. Radiographs show a humeral fracture. Which part of the humerus is most likely involved in this fracture?

options.label: B
options.text: Junction of the middle and distal third

options.label: C
options.text: Junction of the proximal and middle third

questions.correct_answer: B. Junction of the middle and distal third

questions.text: A 48-year-old female fell on her outstretched right hand and reported shoulder pain. A bruise was noted during the examination, and an X-ray was performed. How would you classify this fracture according to Neer's classification based on the X-ray findings?
questions.explanation:
Neer’s Classification

Management

1 Part Fracture

The fracture line involves 1 part and no displacement.

 

Conservative with an arm sling for 6 weeks, followed by exercises.

 
  • Triangular arm sling

 

 
  • Velpeau bandage

 



 

2 Part Fracture

The fracture line involves two parts and displacement of 1 part.
  • Surgical neck displacement: Closed reduction and immobilization with arm-sling or k-wire.
  • Greater tuberosity displaced (mostly associated with shoulder dislocation): Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).
  • In anatomical neck fractures,
    • Older patients: Hemiarthroplasty (replacement of the humeral head)

3 Part Fracture

The fracture line involves 3 parts and displacement of 2 parts.


 

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with Proximal humerus interlocking system plate (PHILOS).

4 Part Fracture

The fracture line involves all 4 parts and displacement of 3 parts.

(High chances of avascular necrosis).

Arthroplasty with shoulder joint replacement.

questions.text: A 29-year-old boxer received a blow to his arm and presented to the emergency department with severe pain, swelling, and deformity in his left upper arm. He reports difficulty moving his elbow and hand and weakness in his wrist. An X-ray was taken. All the following are management options for this condition except?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Image

U-slab

(Option A)
  • Supported with a triangular sling
  • Moulded on the lateral side of the arm (prevent lateral angulation)

 

Hanging arm cast

(Option B)
  • Used in lower 1/3rd fractures of the humerus
  • The limb's weight and the cast provide traction to keep the fracture aligned.

Chest-arm bandage
  • The arm is strapped to the chest

Technique

Description

Image

Internal fixation with plate and screw

It consists of:

  • Compression plate and screws
  • Interlocking intramedullary nail or semi-flexible pins
  • External fixator

Minimally invasive plate osteosynthesis (MIPO)

(Option D)
  • The plate is placed over the comminution without disturbing the fragments, and no graft is utilised.
  • Fracture alignment is preserved without compression.

Russell-Taylors (RT) nailing technique

This procedure avoids radial nerve injury (wrist drop).

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain and tenderness after sustaining an injury from a fall. An X-ray of the region is provided below. Considering the mechanisms of injury, what is the most common cause associated with this condition?

A 30-year-old male presents with recurrent shoulder dislocations after playing basketball & shows the attitude as shown in the image. Which of the following tests is specifically used to assess this shoulder instability?
questions.explanation:
Test

Description

Image

Apprehension test

(Option D)

With the patient seated or supine, the examiner abducts the arm and externally rotates it. The patient may feel the humeral head about to slip anteriorly, leading to tension and apprehension.

Fulcrum test

(Option A)

With the patient lying supine and the arm abducted to 90°, the examiner uses one hand behind the shoulder as a fulcrum to lever the humeral head forward by extending and laterally rotating the arm, leading to immediate apprehension.

Crank test

With the arm flexed at 90°, the examiner applies an axial load to the humerus and rotates it while elevating the shoulder.

A positive test shows pain or a clicking sensation.

Jobe’s relocation test (or) Supraspinatus test

(Option B)

Positioning the shoulder at 90° of abduction and 30° of forward flexion with the thumb down, resistance testing reveals supraspinatus weakness, indicating a possible tear or rotator cuff impingement.

Surprise test

In the relocation test, a posterior force is applied to the humeral head and then suddenly released. The test is considered positive if the patient experiences apprehension or fear of dislocation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male arrives at the emergency department with severe right shoulder pain after a fall during a workout. His shoulder appears deformed, with swelling and bruising. An orthopaedic manoeuvre is performed, as shown in the image. What is the name of this technique?

A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency after a soccer match with severe right shoulder pain following a fall. He reports a "pop" in his shoulder and is unable to lift his arm or touch the opposite shoulder. An X-ray has been taken. What is the appropriate management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: External rotation → Adduction → Traction → Medial rotation

options.label: B
options.text: Traction → Medial rotation → Adduction → External rotation

options.label: C
options.text: Traction → External rotation → Adduction → Medial rotation

options.label: D
options.text: Medial rotation → Traction → External rotation → Adduction

questions.correct_answer: C. Traction → External rotation → Adduction → Medial rotation

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with severe pain in his right shoulder following a tackle during a rugby match. Upon examination, a loss of normal shoulder contour is noted. Diagnosis of anterior shoulder dislocation was made. What is the most common complication associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Early Complications

Delayed Complications
  • Rotator cuff tear - Common in the elderly due to degenerative changes in the tendons and less common in younger patients. (Option B)
  • Axillary artery injury - Rare; Occurs with severe trauma (Option B)
  • Nerve injury - The axillary nerve is most commonly affected; other nerve injuries and complete brachial plexus palsy are rare. (Option A)
  • Recurrence - Most common, due to instability.
  • Joint stiffness - Results from prolonged immobility.
  • Unreduced dislocation - Due to missed or undiagnosed dislocation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident with severe pain and immobility in his right shoulder. Examination reveals a flattened shoulder, and he is unable to abduct or externally rotate the arm. An X-ray was taken. What type of dislocation is suspected?
questions.explanation:
Anterior Shoulder dislocation

Subtypes
  • Subglenoid (Option C): The humeral head lies below the glenoid fossa.
  • Subclavicular (Option B): The humeral head is displaced beneath the clavicle.
  • Intrathoracic(Option A): The humeral head dislocates into the thoracic cavity, which is rare.
  • Subcoracoid (Option D): The humeral head lies below the coracoid process.
 

Clinical findings
  • Loss of the deltoid contour (loss of shoulder roundness)
  • The shoulder is extended, abducted and externally rotated.

Clinical tests
  • Duga’s test is the inability to touch the opposite shoulder.
  • Hamilton ruler test is where the gap between the ruler and the arm is lost.
  • Callaway’s test is increased girth of the axilla on the dislocated side.
  • Bryant’s Test is where the anterior axillary fold is displaced downward on the affected side.
  • Regiment batch sign is loss of sensation due to axillary nerve damage.

Imaging
  • X-ray reveals that the humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position)
  • An MRI is necessary to assess soft-tissue injuries and identify Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesions, which are complications of shoulder dislocations and increase the risk of recurrence due to joint instability.

Management
  • Kocher's method (Most common method) is the reduction by traction, external rotation, adduction, and medial rotation.
  • In Hippocrates' method, the surgeon pulls the semi-abducted arm firmly while using his foot in the axilla as a fulcrum to reduce the dislocation.
  • Stimson’s technique is the reduction by applying weight for traction, using the body as counter traction.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with shoulder pain and recurrent anterior dislocations reports instability and weakness during overhead activities. An X-ray is advised. What lesion was observed?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Hill-Sachs lesion

(Option D)

Bankart lesion

(Option C)

Reverse Bankart lesion

(Posterior Bankart)

(Option A)

Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion

(Option B)

Location

Humeral head

Anterior glenoid

Posterior glenoid

Humeral head

Definition

Compression fracture on the posterolateral humeral head

Defect in the anterior labrum and the anterior capsule.

Tear of the posterior labrum and the associated capsule.

Compression fracture on the anteromedial humeral head.

Symptoms

Instability and pain during shoulder movements

Associated Shoulder dislocation type

Anterior

Anterior

Posterior

Posterior

(Surgical correction of this lesion is necessary to prevent osteonecrosis)

questions.text: Match the following images with appropriate tests. 1. a) Dugas test 2. b) Callaway test 3. c) Hamilton ruler test 4. d) Regimen batch sign
questions.explanation:
Tests of Shoulder dislocation

Hamilton's ruler test

Measures the distance from the acromion to the lateral epicondyle with the arm in a neutral position. A lack of gap between the arm and the ruler indicates dislocation.

Dugas test

The inability to touch the opposite shoulder with a shoulder dislocation is typically observed in anterior dislocations.

 

Callaway test

The circumference of the axilla is checked bilaterally using a measuring tape. An increased circumference on the affected side is diagnostic of dislocation.

Bryants test

It involves observing the anterior axillary fold, displaced inferiorly on the affected side in shoulder dislocation.

Regimen batch sign

Loss of sensation over the deltoid on the affected side due to axillary nerve damage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a seizure. He has severe pain and immobility in his right shoulder, which appears flattened and is held in an adducted and internally rotated position. An X-ray is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Anterior dislocation

Posterior dislocation

Inferior dislocation

Frequency

Most common

Not very common

Rare

Mechanism of Injury

Fall on an outstretched hand with an abducted and externally rotated shoulder.

Occurs during seizures or convulsions.

  • A fall onto a flexed, adducted arm.
  • A direct impact to the anterior aspect of the shoulder.
  • A fall onto an outstretched hand.
  • Also called luxatio erecta.
  • Result from a severe hyper-abduction force.

Clinical presentation

Pain, swelling and movement restriction.

Tests

Duga’s test, Hamilton ruler test and Regimental badge test.

Callaway’s test and Regimental badge test

Bryant’s test

Arm Position

Abduction and external rotation

Adduction and internal rotation

Arm locked in hyperabduction with the hand positioned above the head.

X-ray Findings
  • The humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position).
  • "Hill-Sachs lesion" (compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head).

 
  • The humeral head is displaced posteriorly, appearing closer to the scapula.
  • ‘Light bulb sign’(humeral head appears rounded due to internal rotation).
  • ‘Rim sign’ (widening of the glenohumeral joint space).
  • ‘Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion’ (compression fracture on the anteromedial humeral head).

 

The humeral head is displaced inferiorly below the glenoid cavity.

 

Management

Reduction techniques:

  • Kocher's method (Most commonly used)
  • Hippocrates method
  • Stimson’s technique

Reduction and immobility, followed by active exercises.


 
  • Closed reduction
  • Open reduction if soft tissue injuries are present
  • Re-examination after reduction to avoid neurovascular injuries.

Complications
  • Early:
    • Neurovascular injuries
    • Rotator cuff tear
  • Delayed:
    • Recurrence
    • Stiffness
    • Unreduced dislocation
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation
  • Neurovascular injuries
  • Recurrence
  • Unreduced dislocation

questions.text: A 30-year-old male athlete presents with shoulder pain and instability after a football injury. Examination reveals anterior dislocation of the humeral head. Which of the following provides static stability to the shoulder joint?
questions.explanation:
Static Stabilizers

Dynamic Stabilizers
  • Glenoid labrum: Enhances stability by deepening the glenoid cavity.
  • Glenohumeral ligaments (Superior, Middle, and Inferior Ligaments) form the glenohumeral joint capsule (c), connecting the glenoid fossa to the humerus.
  • Coracoclavicular ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Long Head of the Biceps Tendon (d): Provides stability and support.
  • Rotator Cuff Muscles:
    • Supraspinatus (a): Assists in the abduction and stabilises the head of the humerus.
    • Infraspinatus: External rotation and stabilisation.
    • Teres Minor (b): External rotation and stabilisation.
    • Subscapularis: Internal rotation and stabilization.
  • Deltoid (Option D): It facilitates arm movements such as abduction, flexion, and rotation while stabilizing the shoulder joint.
  • Periscapular muscles: Stabilize the scapula & shoulder joint during movement.

questions.text: A one-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after a fall, and the caregiver reports mild pain over the right shoulder while the child remains active. An X-ray is provided. What is the most appropriate treatment option for managing this condition?
questions.explanation:
Age Group

Management Approach

Newborn to Pre-Ambulatory Children
  • Symptomatic treatment with the arm bound to the chest or a cuff and collar sling.
  • Figure-of-8 bandages are not used for children under two years.

Ambulatory Children (2–12 years)

Use figure-of-8 bandages, tightened after three days and again after one week.

Age >12 years

Commercially available figure-of-8 harnesses are recommended.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents after a fall onto his shoulder. He complains of pain and difficulty moving the affected arm. Based on the clinical presentation and x-ray findings shown in the image, which of the following statements is true regarding the condition and its complications? Injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus is more common than medial cord Malunion is the most common complication Subclavian vessels are at more risk of injury Shoulder stiffness occurs as a late complication

A 30-year-old patient arrives at the emergency department after falling onto the shoulder & reports severe pain and tenderness in the shoulder, with noticeable swelling. X-ray findings are given in the image below. What is the most common site associated with this condition?
